The Timor-Leste National Police - Strengthening Governance Service Delivery Project builds on previous support to key PNTL managerial and administration functions by supporting systematic changes at the central level and ensuring this translates into delivery tangible results at the local level. These formulated project outputs are aligned with the strategic priorities outlined in National Police Strategic Plan (2014 -2018) and will be accompanied by a capacity building strategy to ensure sustainability. title.narrative: Strengthening The Resilience of Small Scale Rural Infrastructure and Local Government Systems

description.narrative: Strengthening The Resilience of Small Scale Rural Infrastructure and Local Government Systems to Climate Variability and Risk.

To strenghthening awareness of community on the climate change related and the small scale infrastrucuture and local government system to climate variabilty and risk in three Districts Ermera, Liquica and Baucau.
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
capital of a political entity
first-order administrative division

1. Number and type of stakeholders served by the multi-sector knowledge sharing and policy influencing platform of MCIE (; 2. Number of evidenced-based climate change risk/vulnerability assessment reports and policy recommendation documents, timely disseminated through the knowledge sharing and policy influencing platform 3. #of sectors which have endorsed MCIE's national climate change framework and strategy, and which have subsequently translated and/or integrated climate risks in key sector policies (4 sectors) 4. No of climate change vulnerability guidelines developed under the project are accepted by MSA as integral part of local planning and budgeting process (yes/no) 5. Number of sub-districts which use climate change vulnerability assessments and CC adaptation activity identification guidelines/tools as integral part of the local development and planning and budgeting process 6. # of (districts) engineering and contractor staff in focus Districts with a solid understanding of climate-induced risks to small scale infrastructure works and of possible adaptation and mitigation measures (design, construction, maintenance) 7. Number of Local Administrations (Districts and Sucos) which invest in climate resilient small rural infrastructure works, including complementary soil and land management measures as integral part of the local infrastructure development process 8. # of people benefiting from climate resilient small scale infrastructure works which are constructed in accordance with climate resilient design in the three project focus Districts 9. Number of Hectares of complementary soil and land management measures in 3 districts (target 5,000)

comment.narrative: 1. 16 multi-lateral and international organizations comprise an existing Climate Change Adaptation Working Group chaired by and 0 participation of policy makers from line agencies. 2. 0 evidence-based climate change risk / vulnerability assessment and policy recommendation documents shared through the platform. 3. 0 sectors endorsed MCIE’s National Climate Change Framework and Strategy as such Framework and Strategy does not exist yet 4. 0 climate change vulnerability guidelines developed as integral part of local planning and budgeting process under MSA. 5. 0 sub-districts use climate change vulnerability assessments and CC adaptation as integral part of the local development and planning and budgeting process 6. 0 Engineering staff and contractors at district level have very little understanding of requirements for climate resilient infrastructure development. 7. 0 local administrations which invest on climate resilient small rural infrastructure works, including complementary soil and land management measures as integral part of the local infrastructure development process 8. 0 people benefitting from climate resilient small scale infrastructure works which are constructed in accordance with climate resilient design in the three project focus municipalities 9. 0 hectares of land have administered complementary soil and land management measures in the target Administrative Posts.

1. Climate change vulnerability assessment conducted and guidelines developed. 2. At least 100 (municipality) engineering and 30 contractor staff have received capacity development and have solid understanding of climate-induced risks to small scale infrastructure works and of possible adaptation and mitigation measures (design, construction, maintenance) 3. 3 municipalities, 8 Administrative Posts (sub-districts) use the new climate change vulnerability assessments and have identified and implemented climate resilient designs and climate risk protection measures for small scale infrastructure works 4. At least 100,000 people benefited from climate resilient small scale infrastructure works in the 3 focus Districts 5. A minimum of (total) 5,000 hectares of catchment and slope stabilization measures have been implemented

1. YES. Guidelines for mainstreaming climate change into MSA District Development Plans and project implementation were produced and included into the revised (MSA) PDIM Planning Manual:Procurement Manual, and Decree Law no. 4/2012.
2. 90 District technical staff and 106 pre-qualified private contractors were trained on aspects of climate-resilient infrastructure planning and implementation 3. 3 municipalities have District Investment Plans (PID) for Baucau, Ermera and Liquica which included climate resilient projects for implementation. 4. The 10 projects are estimated to benefit approximately 69,603 people in rural communities representing a 68% progress against the entire project life target. 5. approx.14,000 ha

1. By the end of the project the climate change vulnerability guidelines and tools to become an integral part of the national local planning and budgeting process as endorsed by MSA. 2. By the end of the project at least 200 (district) engineering and contractor staff have a solid understanding of climate-induced risks to small scale infrastructure works and of possible adaptation and mitigation measures (design, construction, maintenance). 3. In at least 3 districts, ten sub-districts, various new small scale infrastructure works are constructed in accordance with the new climate resilient designs and additional measures are implemented to safeguard existing infrastructure works against climate risks, benefitting at least 100,000 people.* 4. A minimum of (total) 50,000 hectares of catchment stabilization measures have been implemented.

1. YES. Guidelines for mainstreaming climate change into MSA District Development Plans and project implementation were produced and included into the revised (MSA) PDIM Planning Manual:Procurement Manual, and Decree Law no. 4/2012. 2. More than 200 engineering and contractor staff in focus Municipalities have a better understanding of climate-induced risks to small scale infrastructure works and of possible adaptation and mitigation measures (design, construction, maintenance). 3. 3 focus districts, 8 sub districts included more than 10 water supply systems, 2 irrigation schemes, 1 river embankment protection, 6 rural road construction/rehabilitation projects and small bridges and culverts rehabilitation. The infrastructure delivered provides direct benefits and improvement in the social and economic status of rural beneficiaries. Overall 20 contracts were awarded to local construction companies to implement infrastructure projects that also include soil bioengineering interventions in high risk areas/hot-spots vulnerable to climate induced risks such as erosion and landslides. 4. 20 infrastructures benefiting approx. 100,000 people 5. The total area covered during the implementation of bioengineering activities is 3400 hectares benefitting a population of 11,674 (4,774 female) across 4 villages.

description.narrative: Critical small scale rural infrastructure is climate resilient designed and implemented through participatory approaches and strengthened local governance systems reflecting the needs of communities vulnerable to increasing climate risks

Number of sectorspecific standard designs and specifications for small infrastructure works which have been upgraded to address andor withstand increased climate risks
Percentage change in number of subdistrict level annual development plans which include climate risk mitigationresilience measures as climate resilient activity designs of small infrastructure works and complementary bioengineering and land management measures AMAT 1111

comment.narrative:
Designs for small scale infrastructure works insufficiently address present and projected increased climate variability especially in terms of future water resource availability and intensity of extreme weather events leading to capital loss due to inappropriate designs and unnecessary asset loss due to extreme weather events and inadequate maintenance
Within the existing participatory local planning process localized climate risks and vulnerabilities are not analyzed and climate risks for small infrastructure works are not understood nor planned and budgeted for

By the end of the project climate resilient designs are developed for all small scale infrastructure works constructed through the project and 75 of these climate resilient designs are accepted by national level sector agencies as the nationwide standard design
By the end of the project a minimum of 50 of subdistrict annual development plans in the project areas include at least 3 specific climate risk mitigationresilience actions

Completed climateresilient designs for smallscale infrastructure and Bills of Quantities BoQs including climate proofing and bioengineering components for 11 climate resilient projects as part of the government District Investment Development Plan PDID projects to be implemented in 2015 This represents 183 of the 60 total districts PDID projects as a portion of the overall district development plan priorities to be implemented by government in 2015

description.narrative: Local Administrations integrate climate risks into participatory planning budgeting and standards of small scale rural infrastructure development

Climate change vulnerability guidelines and tools developed under the project are accepted by MSA as integral part of local planning and budgeting process YesNo
Percentage of Subdistricts which use climate change vulnerability assessments and CC adaptation activity identification guidelinestools as integral part of the local development and planning and budgeting process AMAT 1113
Number of district engineering and contractor staff in focus Districts with a solid understanding of climateinduced risks to small scale infrastructure works and of possible adaptation and mitigation measures design construction maintenance

comment.narrative:
Within the existing participatory local planning and budgeting process at present localized climate risks and vulnerabilities are not analyzed and climate risks for small infrastructure works are not understood nor are resilience and protective measures planned and budgeted for
Local Administrations have little understanding of their role in terms of ensuring climate resilient development and climate risk resilient small scale infrastructure
Engineering staff and contractors at District level have very little understanding of requirements for climate resilient infrastructure development

By the end of the project the climate change vulnerability guidelines and tools have become an integral part of the national local planning and budgeting process as endorsed by MSA
At least 75 of Subdistricts in 3 Districts use the new climate change vulnerability assessments and have identified and implemented climate resilient designs and climate risk protection measures for small scale infrastructure works
By the end of the project at least 200 district engineering and contractor staff have a solid understanding of climateinduced risks to small scale infrastructure works and of possible adaptation and mitigation measures design construction maintenance

Guidelines for mainstreaming climate change into MSA PDIDs and project implementation have been produced and included into the revised Ministry of State Administration MSA PDID Planning Manual Procurement Manual and Decree Law no 42012
Six 06 subdistricts now renamed Administrative PostsAPs out of a total of 14 APs representing 429 are implementing climate resilient projects in 2015
Three District Investment Plans PID for Baucau Ermera and Liquica included climate resilient projects for implementation in 2015
90 District technical staff and 106 prequalified private contractors were trained on aspects of climateresilient infrastructure planning and implementation

description.narrative: Policy makers and the public in Timor Leste are aware of critical climate risks to rural infrastructure development and are systematically being informed on up to date evidencebased information on climate hazards through vulnerability assessment and cross government coordination mechanisms

number and type of stakeholders served by the multisector knowledge sharing and policy influencing platform of MCIE
Number of evidence climate change riskvulnerability assessment reports and policy recommendation documents timely disseminated through the knowledge sharing and policy influence platform
Number of sectors which have endorsed MCIEs national climate change policy framework and strategy and which have subsequently translated andor integrated climate risks in key sector policies

comment.narrative:
Policy makers have little awareness and understanding of climate risks on sector development goals sector policies do not or insufficiently address climate risks and vulnerabilities
Due to sector fragmentation little exchange of knowledge lessons and experiences takes place existing platforms are shaped around national programmes like NAPA working group but do not function adequately outside the framework of these programmes due to limited capacity of MCIENDIEACC for multistakeholder process facilitation and sector leadership

Atleast 5 platform members from relevant National Directorates and 2 members each from or one representative organization Local Administration Civil Society private sector International NGOs education institutions
Atleast five evidencebased policy influencing documents disseminated through the platform
Atleast 4 sectors have formally endorsed the MCIE climate change policy framework and strategy and have translated or integrated climate risk concerns into atleast 1 sector policy

Members of four line Ministries namely Ministry of Social Solidarity MSS Ministry of Public Works MPW Ministry of State Administration MSA Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry MoAF participated in the Climate change Forum meetings organized by Ministry of Commerce Industry and Environment MCIE coordinated National Climate Change Adaptation Forum
Secondary data about climate risks and natural disaster affecting rural infrastructure collected and collated to facilitate the Ministry of Commerce Industry and Environment MCIE undertake its policy advocacy work
One sector Ministry of State Administration MSA incorporated climate resilience and EIA and social safeguards into the planning implementation of its rural infrastructure under the PDID programme for community level service delivery

description.narrative: Small scale rural infrastructure made resilient against climate change induced risks droughts floods erosion and landslides in at least the 3 Districts of Liquiça Ermera and Baucau Physical Investment Component

Number of Local Administrations Districts and Sucos which invest in climate resilient small rural infrastructure works including complementary soil and land management measures as integral part of the local infrastructure development process
Number of people benefiting from climate resilient small scale infrastructure works which are constructed in accordance with climate resilient designs in the three project focus Districts target 100000 AMAT 1212
Coverage in Hectares of complementary soil and land management measures in 3 Districts target 50000

comment.narrative: Designs for small scale infrastructure works implemented at the Local Administration level are often prepared by national level sector departments or agencies These designs are at present not climate resilient nor adapted to local conditions Local Administrations also lack the capacity to make climate resilient designs and to construct in accordance with required higher quality standards

In at least ten subdistricts in 3 Districts various new small scale infrastructure works are constructed in accordance with the new climate resilient designs and additional measures are implemented to safeguard existing infrastructure works against climate risks benefitting at least 100000 people
At least 100000 people benefited from climate resilient small scale infrastructure works in the 3 focus Districts
A minimum of total 50000 hectares of catchment stabilization measures have been implemented
Note The 50000 hectare target was deemed overly ambitious and reduced to 5000 hactares during the inception workshop refer to inception workshop report

Implementation of 11 climate resilient pilot projects commenced in six 06 subdistricts now APs the three districts now named Municipalities
The 11 projects are will benefit approximately 68000 people in rural communities representing a 68 progress against the entire project life target
The draft Climate Vulnerability and Capacity Assessment CVCA has identified approx14000 hactares of degraded hotspot areas affected by landslides and approx125287 ha of land affected by erosion that require rehabilitation

activity-description.narrative: knowledge and understanding of local drivers of climate induced disasters enhanced, and consequent impacts on economic infrastructure better understood and available to policy makers, planners and technical staff

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. No. of target institutions with increased capacity for climate and disaster risk management, planning, budgeting and delivery at the national and sub-national level. 2. No. of targeted institutions with increased adaptive capacity to reduce risks of and response to climate variability. 3. No. of staff trained on technical CCA and DRM themes, disaggregated by gender. 4. Type and no. of recommendations to sector policies, strategies, and plans for climate change adaptation and DRM that specifically address needs of women. 5. Increase in amount of funds delivered on climate risk reduction measures at the sub-national/district level. 6. % of women benefited from community-level climate risk reduction measures. 7. Risk reduction and awareness activities introduced at local level, including: (i) EWS; (ii) improved resilience of agriculture systems; (iii) Erosion control/sustainable land and water management. 8. No. of households engaged in climate resilient land use methods and livelihoods disaggregated by gender. 9. Coverage of land with changed land use conducive to landscape stability, protecting livelihoods and physical infrastructures against climate hazards risk and disasters. 10. % of households that demonstrate an awareness between improved land use and food security/disaster mitigation through their livelihoods-disaggregated by gender.

comment.narrative: 1. Capacity for climate and disaster risk planning, budgeting and delivery at the national and sub-national level is limited 2. MSS, NDMD, DDMCs and other institutions have limited capacity to reduce risks and respond to climate variability. 3. Few staffs and community leaders have received comprehensive technical training on CCA and DRM themes. 4. Sector policies strategies and plans do not explicitly include climate change adaptation and DRM, and do not specifically address the needs of women concerning climate change and DRM. 5. Few measures for community-level disaster mitigation are currently implemented through DDMCs/district disaster focal points. 6. Women are rarely direct beneficiaries of measures for community-level disaster prevention and preparedness. 7. Few households currently benefit from risk reduction and awareness activities. 8. Few households have access to resilient livelihoods and methods 9. No Early Warning Systems (EWS) are currently in place. 10. No watershed management plans do exist. 11. Currently land left behind in shifting, slash-and-burn agriculture are left to recover without intervention and are a major source of vulnerability for communities and the road. 12. Current understanding of the links between land use and livelihoods, food and nutrition security and disasters is low.

1. MSS, NDMD, DDMCs have capacity for climate and disaster risk management planning, budgeting and delivery at the national and sub-national (at least Level 4: Widespread, but not comprehensive, evidence of capacity) 2. MSS, NDMD, DDMCs, MAF and other institutions have increased adaptive capacity to reduce risks and respond to climate variability 3. 200 staff and community leaders have receive technical training on CCA and DRM themes with at least 50% women benefiting 4. Recommendations for at least 3 sector policies, strategies and plans that explicitly include climate change adaptation and DRM. Recommendations for at least 3 sector policies, strategies and plans specifically address the needs of women concerning climate change adaptation and DRM. 5. Full expenditure of additional funds ($50,000 per district per annum) on measures for community-level climate risk reduction implemented through DDMCs/district disaster focal points 6. 50% of beneficiaries of community-level measures for climate related disaster risk reduction and preparedness are women 7. At least 5,000 households will benefit from risk reduction activities and awareness activities comprising: - EWS - Improved resilience of agricultural systems - Erosion control/sustainable land and water management 8. Score improved to 4: By the end of the project, at least 50% of targeted households have engaged in climate resilient land use methods and livelihoods introduced/strengthened in the project. at least a quarter of targeted area of degraded lands reforested or other land stabilization methods applied (e.g. agroforestry, fodder and timber production etc.) while decreasing vulnerability of the DARDC to disasters 9. At least 50% of households surveyed confirm a clear link between resource management and resilience of livelihoods and physical infrastructure assets

-The DRM training manual has been finalized which will become a part of INAP's mandatory curricula for capacity building of government officials.
- Timor Leste online disaster database (tldd.mss.gov.tl) has been developed and launched for DRM planning.
-15 person trained for drone application to build the capacity of DRM institutions on disaster monitoring
-6 experts from MAF and MSS trained for GIS application for DRR planning in Bogor
- Hazard maps developed and given to municipal office for planning.
-6 sets of automatic weather stations purchased for early warning and planning for DRR -capacity of DRM institutions has been assessed and the draft report has been submitted.
-DRM training manual has been finalized and integrated with INAP curricula.
-15 MSS and MAF staff has been trained to use drone technology for disaster monitoring. Two sets of drones have been purchased to build monitoring capacity of the government.
-22 INAP & MSS staff were trained as Trainers (ToT). This has built the capacity of INAP and DRM institutions to build capacity of communities and local staff.
-260 Civil servants form 12 Municipalities include Especial Economic Region Oecussi ( Directors from other line Ministries such as, MAF, PNTL, Post Administrative, Public Works, MCIE, Educations, health, civil protections) on the Disaster risk assessment, DRM and integrating DRM activities into the local level planning process - Gender action plan prepared for DRM interventions
- Gender policy brief has been prepared and shared
- Top up grant mechanism policy brief prepared as a special bulletin - Top up mechanism has been finalized and launched.
- Financial mechanism for top grant project implementation has been developed.
-Municipality officials (8) were trained on the financial mechanism
-7 community water supply projects under top grant mechanism have been completed.
A total of 9853 people benefitted from 7 water supply projects – at least 50% of them

Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1) A country level vulnerability and adaptation assessment prepared 2) # of people trained in global climate change including UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, greenhouse gas inventories, mitigation, and adaptation analysis. 3) # of GoTL institutions capacitized on GHG inventory preparation 4) Development of baseline for GHG inventory prepared 5) # of GoTL officials trained on vulnerability and adaptation assessment 6) # of national public awareness campaign and events on climate change to enhance mass awareness 7) # of climate change related knowledge product developed 8) Constraints and gaps mapped, financial resources and technical support provided, country specific technology needs assessed.

•UNDP-UNCDF formulated SNGDP to support the Government of Timor-Leste. The SNGDP will be commenced from 1st July 2014 and will be implemented during the period of four (4) years, 1st July 2014 to 30 June 2018.

description.narrative:
CPD and IRRF Outcome indicator
1. Number of voters registered for democratic participation 2. Percentage of Voter Turnout (as an indication greater democratic participation) 3. Percentage of invalid ballots decrease indicating the effectiveness of voter education 4. Percentage of women as polling staff for elections

comment.narrative:
1. Number of Registered Electorates in the Presidential Elections 2012- 626,503 (Gender Disaggregated data- Not Available)
2. Voter Turnout in the Presidential Elections 2012- 72.55% (Gender Disaggregated Turnout- Not available)
3. Invalid Ballots in the Presidential election 2012- 3.83%
4. Number of women polling staff deployed- Not Available

1. 18% Increase in number of registered electorates for the Parliamentary Elections. 2. 75% Voters’ turnout in the National Parliament Elections 3. 50% women vote in the National Parliament Elections 4. Invalid ballots to be below 2% in National Parliament Elections 5. At the 2017 National Parliament Elections 6. 50% of the Polling Staff to be women.

1. Total of Registered Voters for 2017 National Parliament Elections: 760,907 Male: 51.65% Female: 48.35% 17% Increase in number of registered electorates in comparison with the baseline data (year 2012).
2. Voter turnout in the 2017 Presidential Elections: 71.16% 47% women voted in the 2017 Presidential Elections. Voter turnout in the 2017 Parliamentary Elections:76.74%
3. Presidential Election 2017 witnessed 1.7% invalid ballots. Parliamentary Election 2017 witnessed 1.9% invalid ballots.
4.There was a total of 10,102 polling staff deployed for the 2017 presidential election, i.e. 50% of the total polling staff were women.

title.narrative: Building shoreline resilience of Timor-Leste to protect

description.narrative: Building shoreline resilience of Timor-Leste to protect local communities and their livelihoods

title.narrative: Call for Proposals - Selection of NGOs/CBOs to implement Community-Based Ecological Mangroves Restoration Activities in Bobonaro, Dili, Liquica, Manatutu, Maunufahi, Viqueque and Covalima Districts in Timor-Leste
Community Based Mangroves Restoration and Sustainable Land Management (SLM) Specialist
International Consultant for Economic Analysis of Mangrove Ecosystem Supportive Livelihoods Options for Costal Community of Timor-Leste
Rapid Shoreline and Sea Level Rise Assessment Consultant
RFP 008/TLS/2017 Supply of Tidal Gauging and Sea Level Rise Instruments and Provision of Related Expert Training
RFP 009/TLS/2016 For Selection of Consulting Firm to Conduct Coastal Vulnerability Assessment, Coastal Management and Adaptation Strategy in Timor-Leste
RFP 009/TLS/2016 Selection of Consulting Firm to Conduct Coastal Vulnerability Assessment and Develop an Integrated Coastal Adaptation and Management Strategic Plan for Timor-Leste - Re-advertised

description.narrative: Solution developed at national and sub national level for sustainable management of natural resources, ecosystem services and waste. Scaled up action on climate change adaptation and mitigation across sectors which is funded and implemented.
first-order administrative division

1) Regional, national and sector-wide policies, plans and processes developed and strengthened to identify, prioritize and integrate adaptation strategies and measures. (LDCF Indicator 12 2) 250ha protected or re-afforested using CBEMR 3) Type and extent of assets strengthened and/or better managed to withstand the effects of climate change (UNDAF Indicator 3.2.3, LDCF Indicator 2) 4) Number of population / households benefiting from the adoption of diversified, climate-resilient livelihood options (LDCF Indicator 3) 5) % target population aware of role of mangroves in coastal protection and coastal watershed protection

comment.narrative:
1) This is currently no coastal protection and resilience strategy for infrastructure planning in place
2) ~1,300ha of mangroves in Timor-Leste (2005) 3) 0 – project will introduce livelihood options, which contribute to protection and re-afforestation efforts and/or relieve community pressure on mangroves 4) Baseline study to be conducted at start of project to assess current household income levels (see Annex H – Randomized Control Trials) 5) There is little-to-no educational or public awareness material, especially targeted at youth, about the role of mangroves in coastal ecosystems

1) Integrated coastal adaptation plan drafted 2) 250ha protected or re-afforested using CBEMR 3) 250 households benefiting from mangrove-supportive livelihoods 4) 30% of livelihoods support will target women 5) Print material, videos (TV), community events to raise public awareness about the role of mangroves in coastal ecosystems, reaching especially youth and school-aged population in coastal areas, approximately 50,000 people

1) Based on the comprehensive Coastal vulnerability assessment findings an integrated coastal adaptation plan drafted which is intended to be used as a guideline to prepare and implement national and district specific coastal adaptation management actions 2) The sensitized and mobilized community 11 sites able to fence 890 ha of mangroves and wetlands, prepared 30,550 different types of mangroves seedling and planted 6850 mangrove seedlings planted. This significant achievement will result in restoring and rehabilitating the highly degraded mangroves areas of Timor Leste. 3) The business skills and technical trainings provided enabled 620 households of which 264 are women commence various income generating activities that are supportive to mangrove protection and conservation; fishery, horticulture, agroforestry, handicraft 4) 42.6 % of target beneficiaries of the livelihoods strengthening activities are women, participating in such activities significantly empower them in addition to strengthening their family livelihoods 5) The sensitization and awareness raising activities improved the knowledge and awareness of 10,766 through direct workshops, sensitization, school events, youth symposium, trainings, consultation, etc. more than 47,000 population reached through media engagement, campaign, dissemination of booklets, newspapers, leaflets, Facebook, tweeter, web- based information sharing

Anti corruption

This component will adopt a UNDP’s global strategy called the ART Initiative (Articulation of Territorial Networks for Sustainable Human Development) to support decentralized public administration focused on the capacity development of civil servants.

GCF Readiness project. PIMS ID for the project is 5988. Title of project is GCF Readiness Support to Timor-Leste

title.narrative: International Consultant FOR INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT SPECIALIST
Junior Expert (National Consultant) for GCF Readiness Support Project
Senior Expert (National Consultant) for GCF Readiness

description.narrative: The GCF Readiness project focuses on two areas: 1. Establishing and strengthening the proposed National Designated Authority (NDA) and Focal Point), and 2 (Development of a Strategic Framework)
capital of a political entity

1.1 Capacity to coordinate across stakeholders and facilitate effective consultation and communication 1.2 Knowledge on climate and finance priorities strengthened 1.3 System for reviewing proposals and issuing recommendations (or no-objections) established 1.4 Capacity and systems to monitor, evaluate and report on the activities of the Fund and other relevant finance mechanisms and institutions established 1.5 Information, including in local languages, on procedures of the Fund to disseminated to country stakeholders

comment.narrative: • NDA/focal point lead effective coordination mechanism • No objection procedure established and implemented • Stakeholders engages in consultative processes • Stakeholder consultations conducted with equal representation of women • Bilateral agreements between the country and the GCF executed • Monitoring, oversight and streamlining of climate finance • Country programmes, including adaptation priorities, developed and continuously updated • Annual participatory review of GCF portfolio in the country organized
NA. no activities undertaken in this year.

• NDA/focal point lead effective coordination mechanism • No objection procedure established and implemented • Stakeholders engages in consultative processes • Stakeholder consultations conducted with equal representation of women • Bilateral agreements between the country and the GCF executed • Monitoring, oversight and streamlining of climate finance • Country programmes, including adaptation priorities, developed and continuously updated • Annual participatory review of GCF portfolio in the country organized

The de facto NDA is currently functioning and effectively leading and coordinating with a wide range of key stakeholders for NDA related activities as well as general climate activities that are ongoing in the country; 53 (female: 22, Male: 31) stakeholders participated in this consultation.
The no objection procedure has been established, but may be subject to due to the current political situation in the country. The no-objection procedure has not been implemented as there has been no proposal etc. submitted since the no-objection procedure was established.
The draft stakeholder engagement is ongoing Stocktaking exercise was undertaken with each line ministries plans and priorities as part of the country programme was initiated and will be finalized in May 2018
Stakeholder consultations was conducted.
